intro: Macraea laricifolia, commonly known as the "cedar tree of the forest," is a deciduous tree native to tropical Africa. It belongs to the family Fabaceae and is characterized by its tall, straight trunk and broad, compound leaves. The tree produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in racemes, followed by flat, pod-like fruits. It is often found in moist, shaded areas of lowland forests and is valued for its timber and ecological role. Its botanical features make it an important component of the biodiversity in its native habitat.
